questions.clue: This invention by Johannes Gutenberg in the 15th century revolutionized the way books were produced and distributed.
Developed in 1876 by Alexander Graham Bell, this device was the first to enable voice communication over distances.
Credited to Eli Whitney, this 1793 invention had a major impact on the cotton industry and slavery in the United States.
This ancient Greek engineer is said to have created a steam-powered device known as an 'aeolipile', demonstrating the potential for steam propulsion.
This revolutionary 1969 innovation, developed by the U.S. Department of Defense, was the precursor to the internet.
This famous festival on the first of March in Venice, Italy is renowned for its elaborate masks.
In India's Tamil Nadu, this harvest festival is celebrated in January with cattle races.
Every July, Pamplona, Spain is famous for hosting the Running of the Bulls during this festival.
In Rio de Janeiro, this samba-filled event is known as the world's largest carnival.
Observing the end of Ramadan, this Islamic festival varies by country but is marked by prayer and feasting.
This 'Great Expectations' character was raised by a blacksmith and went on to become a gentleman.
In 'Moby-Dick', this captain's obsession with the white whale leads to tragic consequences.
This character from 'Pride and Prejudice' is known for her wit and is the second eldest of the Bennet sisters.
In 'Crime and Punishment', this impoverished student commits a murder leading to his moral and mental downfall.
This character in 'The Brothers Karamazov' represents the radical intellectual and skeptic among the Karamazov brothers.
At the heart of quantum mechanics is this principle, stating that certain pairs of properties cannot both be known to arbitrary precision.
A fundamental aspect of quantum theory, this phenomenon shows particles existing in multiple states until measured.
These hypothetical one-dimensional objects are believed to be the fundamental building blocks in theories beyond quantum physics.
The paradox of a cat that is simultaneously alive and dead is named after this physicist.
This thought experiment by Einstein, Podolsky, and Rosen highlighted the 'spooky action at a distance' seen in quantum entanglement.
This early 20th-century movement, led by Pablo Picasso and Georges Braque, involved breaking objects into geometric shapes.
Known for its use of vibrant colors and expressive brushstrokes, this movement began with artists like Henri Matisse around 1905.
Associated with abstract art and non-representational forms, this movement originated with Russian artist Kazimir Malevich around 1915.
Founded by the architect Walter Gropius in Weimar in 1919, this German art school became famous for its approach to combining fine arts and crafts.
This avant-garde movement, founded by André Breton, sought to release the creative potential of the unconscious mind.

final.clue: This device, patented in 1876, was described as 'an improvement in telegraphy' and its inventor famously called out 'Mr. Watson, come here, I want to see you.'
